fullText:

title: Nishesh Basavareddy Turns Heads With â€˜Chokeâ€™ Celebration After Rivalâ€™s Error at Australian Open
description: There are moments in tennis when the crowd senses the tide turning long before the players do. And then there are moments â€“ like the one that unfolded on a hot Wednesday afternoon in Melbourne, when even the player in control has absolutely no idea whatâ€™s coming next.
fullText:
There are moments in tennis when the crowd senses the tide turning long before the players do. And then there are moments â€“ like the one that unfolded on a hot Wednesday afternoon in Melbourne, when even the player in control has absolutely no idea whatâ€™s coming next. Austriaâ€™s Sebastian Ofner thought he had sealed the second qualifier at the 2026 AO against Nishesh Basavareddy. But the 20-year-old American had other plansâ€¦

Up 7-1 in the deciding super tie-break, the Austrian raised his arms, pumped his fist, and tapped the side of his head as if reminding the world of his mental edge. He strutted forward, basking in what he believed was a done deal. But the Australian Openâ€˜s qualifying format has one brutal quirk: the third-set tie-break goes to 10, not 7. Ofner didnâ€™t know it. And that moment of premature celebration was all Nishesh Basavareddy needed to swing open a door that had something firmly shut. Just over 10 minutes later, Ofner had lost 13-11 to the American and eventually got eliminated from qualification.

The match ended at 4-6, 6-4, 7-6 (13-11) in favor of Nishesh Basavareddy. Now, coming to his celebrationâ€¦ well, instead of a muted reaction, Basavareddy turned toward the crowd, placed both hands around his throat, and delivered a deliberate â€œchokeâ€ gesture â€“ pointed reference to Ofnerâ€™s early celebration and the unraveling that followed.

It was icy, unapologetic, and brutally symbolic! Even so, Sebastian Ofner met Basavareddy at the net for a handshake before trudging off the court. The mood was surreal: equal parts disbelief and secondhand embarrassment. Moments later, reactions started to pour in on social media.

American tennis journalist Ben Rothenberg tweeted, â€œHoly crap, he lost. After Ofnerâ€™s premature celebration, Basavareddy won eight of the next nine points, then hung on to take the tiebreak 13-11. Wildest ride of the Australian Open so far; should make for some viral videosâ€¦â€ Barstool Tennis didnâ€™t hold back either, calling the whole episode â€œinsanity.â€

Painfully for Ofner, this wasnâ€™t new territory. In 2023 at Kitzbuhel, he led Alex Molcan 6-4, 5-0â€¦ only to lose seven straight games, drop the second set, and eventually lose the match in a tiebreak. Wednesdayâ€™s meltdown felt like deja vu, another match that slipped through his fingers just when it seemed secure.

For Nishesh Basavareddy, though, this was another showcase of the grit heâ€™s been building on the big stage. Now, he moves on to face Britainâ€™s George Loffhager in a bid to enter the main draw. Remember what happened last year?

There arenâ€™t many young players who get a nod of approval from Novak Djokovic before stepping on court with him. And there are even fewer who manage to rattle the 10x AO champion once the match begins. But in 2025, Nishesh Basavareddy did both. Last year, he arrived in Melbourne as a wildcard, a teenager still trying to find his place in the crowded world of rising tennis talents. And guess what? He got the chance to face the 24-time Grand Slam champion Novak Djokovic in his very first match.

But before the match, Djokovic was seen rating this youngster pretty highly. â€œI saw that heâ€™s very quick. Heâ€™s a very talented player. Heâ€™s got great hands. Heâ€™s very dynamic. He can serve well, hit spots. Just a very complete game overall. Yeah, I mean, itâ€™s going to be his, I guess, first time in the main draw of the Grand Slam, wild card, playing on the center court. Not much to lose. Iâ€™m sure that he is going to be really pumped to make a statement.â€

Just like what he said, Nishesh Basavareddyâ€™s fearless start in this epic battle earned him the first set against the Serbian superstar. When the American took the opening set 6-4, the arena erupted. But then, Djokovic eventually steadied the ship and won the next three sets to wrap up the match at 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2.

After the match, Novak Djokovic even shared a heartfelt message for the youngster. â€œWell played, Nishesh Basavareddy, impressive slam debut.â€ Even tennis legend Mats Wilander spoke highly of the American.

During his conversation on Eurosport, Wilander said, â€œFirst impression was brilliant. The technique was similar to Novakâ€™s. The forehand was very similar. A better forehand than Novak had when Novak was at his age, because Novak struggled with his forehand early on. He moves well enough. He needs to get a little bit stronger. His serve, technically, I thought was good enough. So he has a bright future and another American youngster.â€

If Novak Djokovicâ€™s early praise was a prediction, Nishesh Basavreddy is already proving him right. How far do you think this young American can reach at the 2026 AO?

The post Nishesh Basavareddy Turns Heads With â€˜Chokeâ€™ Celebration After Rivalâ€™s Error at Australian Open appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Baylor Bears earn first conference win of season over Oklahoma State
description: The Bears found their rhythm in Stillwater.
fullText:
Baylor Bears earn first conference win of season over Oklahoma State originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Baylor men's basketball team finally found itsÂ rhythm in conference play Tuesday night, using a blistering first half to power past Oklahoma State 94-79 at Gallagher-Iba Arena for its first Big 12 win of the season.

Tuesday's win marked Baylorâ€™s 10th straight win in Stillwater and ended Oklahoma Stateâ€™s 11-game home winning streak. The Bears stand 11-5 on the season and now 1-3 in conference play, shot a record-setting 73.3 percent in the opening half, their best first-half performance ever in a Big 12 game, to take control early and never let up.

Yessoufou out here breaking anklesğŸ˜®â€ğŸ’¨#Big12MBB | ğŸ“ºCBSSN pic.twitter.com/wKrIsvbR9o

â€” Big 12 Studios (@big12studios) January 14, 2026

It was a stellar night for freshmanÂ Tounde Yessoufou. He led the Bears with 23 points on 11 field goals, whileÂ Michael RatajÂ added 19 points.Â Cameron CarrÂ had 17,Â Obi AgbimÂ scored 15, andÂ Isaac Williams IVÂ chipped in 14 as five Bears finished in double figures.Â Oklahoma State briefly threatened midway through the second half with an 8-0 run that trimmed the deficit to 72-61. But a steal and slam by Yessoufou halted the surge and deflated any hope of a comeback for the crowd at Gallagher-Iba Arena.

From there, Baylor matched every Cowboys push with timely buckets. Agbim, who played all 40 minutes, hit a key 3-pointer to maintain momentum as the Bears coasted through the final stretch.

Yessoufou sealed the victory in the closing minutes, surpassing 20 points before Baylor closed out its first conference win of 2026. Baylor continues its Big 12 slate Friday night against No. 4 Kansas at Allen Fieldhouse. Tipoff is set for 7 p.m. CT on FOX.

title: Mike Tomlin rumored to be a "top" candidate for AFC head coaching job
description: Mike Tomlin stepped down from his role as the Steelers head coach on Tuesday, but the coach may not have to wait long to find his new role.
fullText:
Mike Tomlin rumored to be a "top" candidate for AFC head coaching job originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Mike Tomlin shocked the NFL world by stepping down from his role as the head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Tomlin had been the head man in Pittsburgh since 2007, won a Super Bowl, and never had a losing record with the team. However, the team failed to advance in the postseason again this season, and it seems like it's time for a change.

There has been some speculation that Tomlin could take a year off, similar to what Mike Vrabel did after splitting with the Titans. However, what if the perfect job is available that Tomlin can't say no to?

NFL insider Josina Anderson is reporting that Tomlin is a "top" candidate for the Miami Dolphins job. The Dolphins fired Mike McDaniel and could be looking for a more experienced option with their next hire.

â€œâ€˜John Harbaugh & Mike Tomlin are at the top of the (Miami Dolphins) wish list (at head coach),â€™ a league source said again just now. Weâ€™ll seeâ€¦if the Dolphins can pull either off,â€ said Anderson. â€œIt takes two to tango."

Anderson was also reportedly told by a source that Tomlin "would prefer to coach in a warm-weather environment, if it fits."

As Anderson mentioned, the Dolphins could be going hard after both Tomlin and John Harbaugh. Both coaches are experienced winners from the AFC North who are somewhat surprisingly available.

The Dolphins certainly need a fresh start. The team has not won a playoff game since the year 2000. The Dolphins made the playoffs in 2022 and 2023, but failed to get back to the postseason in 2024 or 2025.

Tomlin would immediately bring credibility to the Dolphins and would likely make some veterans want to play there.

Of course, there's no guarantee Tomlin would want to start over in Miami. Sure, the weather is nice, but the Dolphins are in a terrible cap situation and are seemingly stuck with Tua Tagovailoa at quarterback.

Would Tomlin prefer to just sit this season out and see what options are available next season? Regardless, it seems like the Dolphins are exploring all options and could be a major player in the market.

title: Peterson and Kansas show their potential as Jayhawks crush previously unbeaten No. 2 Iowa State
description: Kansas finally showed what it could do with a healthy Darryn Peterson and a regular rotation Tuesday night.  The timing couldn't have been worse for second-ranked Iowa State.  After falling from the AP Top 25 following a second loss in their first three Big 12 games, the Jayhawks roared away from the stunned Cyclones the moment the ball was thrown up.
fullText:
LAWRENCE, Kan. (AP) â€” Kansas finally showed what it could do with a healthy Darryn Peterson and a regular rotation Tuesday night.

The timing couldn't have been worse for second-ranked Iowa State.

After falling from the AP Top 25 following a second loss in their first three Big 12 games, the Jayhawks roared away from the stunned Cyclones the moment the ball was thrown up. Tre White hit four early 3-pointers and went on to score 19 points, Peterson contributed 16 before more cramping issues, and Kansas coasted to an 84-63 victory over previously unbeaten Iowa State.

â€œThis is more what I envisioned,â€ Jayhawks coach Bill Self said. â€œWe've got an elite player â€” we got an elite scorer â€” and even tonight, when (Peterson) went to get his own, he can do some things other guys can't do. But the thing is the other guys are good players. We don't need to defer to him. I don't know that we've found that balance yet. But tonight was the closest thing to it.â€

Melvin Council Jr. added 15 points and Flory Bidunga had 10 for the Jayhawks (12-5, 2-2 Big 12), who led by 26 in the first half, had that advantage trimmed to 11 midway through the second, then answered with a 10-0 run to put the game away.

It was the kind of performance that college basketball fans have become accustomed to seeing from the Jayhawks over the years.

Much more familiar than recent losses to unranked UCF and West Virginia.

â€œThey were extremely well-prepared, well-coached, like we knew they would be,â€ Iowa State coach T.J. Otzelberger said. â€œExtremely urgent (for Kansas) to come out and play with a tremendous spirit, which they did, so credit to them.

â€œThat was an absolute beat-down,â€ Otzelberger added, â€œin their favor, unfortunately.â€

There are a multitude of reasons for a stumbling start to the season, which had the Jayhawks in danger of their first 1-3 start to league play since the 1987-88 season. But the biggest may have been the cramping problems that had kept Peterson off the court for long stretches and kept the Jayhawks from getting into a rhythm even when he was available.

He was still massaging his calf on the bench Tuesday night, and at one point, Peterson grabbed it after going high for a dunk. But Self said the issue wasn't as serious as earlier in the year: â€œIt was more of, â€˜Iâ€™m not quite whole right now.'â€

â€œFeeling better. It's coming back slowly to me,â€ Peterson said. â€œI was out for a while but every game is getting better. This was a great win, especially coming off the loss to West Virginia. We knew we had to come out and get a win.â€

The Jayhawks clearly felt a sense of urgency. They even had a players-only meeting â€” Self insisted he knew nothing about it â€” during which they talked about their goals for the season and what it would take to get back on track.

â€œJust kind of reiterating the key things that we want to identify ourselves as this year,â€ White said, â€œand just internal conversations that made us more focused on what we want to do. It definitely made us more connected.â€

It was evident from the opening minutes, when Kansas opened with an 11-3 run to get the crowd into the game.

Kansas pushed the lead to 26 points before Iowa State mounted its only real comeback, stringing together some stops and getting some buckets to go on each side of halftime. But eventually, the Jayhawks found their stride again, and they quickly pushed the lead back over 20 points before emptying the bench in the final minutes.

What made the performance particularly impressive was the opposition: Iowa State was off to a 16-0 start, including a 23-point road win over then-No. 1 Purdue, and the Cyclones were one of two teams receiving No. 1 votes in the AP Top 25 this week.

â€œWe looked a little spooked and panicked, and the moment got to us,â€ Otzelberger said. â€œWe know how well prepared they were going to be. We know how competitive they're going to be. We know how much confidence they have, especially in this building. You can tell they've been on the practice court working, and getting ready, and they did a tremendous job.â€

Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. AP college basketball: https://apnews.com/hub/ap-top-25-college-basketball-poll and https://apnews.com/hub/college-basketball

title: Rick Pitino Offers Cold Reality Check After St. Johnâ€™s Parts Ways With GM Abdelmassih
description: The Red Storm defied odds last season, winning the Big East regular-season championship and their first Big East Tournament title since 2000. But this year has been a different story.
fullText:
The Red Storm defied odds last season, winning the Big East regular-season championship and their first Big East Tournament title since 2000. But this year has been a different story. Rick Pitinoâ€™s side are 12â€“5 to start the season, theyâ€™ve fallen out of the rankings, and that comes with consequences.

St. Johnâ€™s parted ways with general manager Matt Abdelmassih. He was long considered one of the most important figures behind St. Johnâ€™s roster construction and transfer portal strategy. Abdelmassih had been on administrative leave since mid-December. According to journalist Roger Rubin of Newsday Sports, financial deals made by the General Manager had been under investigation in recent weeks, prompting his exit from the program.

When Rick Pitino was asked about the situation, he had a rather cold response. â€œItâ€™s out of my hands. I found out tonight. All I was told four days ago is look for another general manager. They said to me, â€˜ donâ€™t ask any questions.â€™ I said, â€˜Okay, Iâ€™ll look for one.â€™ So, itâ€™s really not a big deal,â€ Pitino said after the win against Marquette.

He continued, â€œWhatâ€™s a big deal is making sure that we donâ€™t lose anything. But thatâ€™s a university decision. Iâ€™ll abide by. They didnâ€™t ask me my opinion, and I didnâ€™t give it because they didnâ€™t, and in their defense, they didnâ€™t want to bother me. They didnâ€™t want to distract me right now, and I appreciate that.â€

title: Boots vs. Ortiz Drama Puts Oscar De La Hoyaâ€™s DAZN Future at Risk
description: Is Golden Boy Promotions headed for the same fate as Top Rank? From the looks of things, the possibility canâ€™t be ruled out entirely. Vergil Ortiz Jr.
fullText:
Is Golden Boy Promotions headed for the same fate as Top Rank? From the looks of things, the possibility canâ€™t be ruled out entirely. Vergil Ortiz Jr., promoted by Golden Boy, and Jaron Ennis, who fights under Matchroom Boxing, have been in negotiations for a potential showdown since late 2025. However, the two sides have yet to finalize an agreement. And the cause appears to be Oscar De La Hoya.

Both fighters are reportedly eager to make the bout happen, and initial talks saw their respective promotions agree to a 50â€“50 purse split, with an additional 5% going to the winner. But negotiations hit another roadblock when Golden Boy head Oscar De La Hoya later demanded a revised 60â€“40 split in Ortizâ€™s favor. That move stalled the fight once again and has now drawn DAZN into the ongoing negotiations.

According to veteran boxing journalist Dan Rafael, Golden Boy Promotionsâ€™ TV deal with DAZN has expired. And they are pressuring the promotion to make the Ortiz vs. Ennis fight to extend the contract. â€œI understand it this way: Golden Boyâ€™s contract with DAZN is expiring and has not officially been renewed. To reach a new agreement, DAZN was putting pressure on De La Hoya with the demand to make the Ennisâ€“Ortiz fight,â€ Rafael said on the Big Fight Weekend podcast.

Oscar De La Hoya, through his Golden Boy Promotions, first partnered with DAZN in October 2018. Since then, the retired world champion has come under scrutiny time and time again for his feuds with his own fighters. His infamous clash with former Golden Boy star Canelo Alvarez saw the two enter court, and Alvarez later even left the promotion. De La Hoya has also found himself at odds with Ryan Garcia on several occasions.

Itâ€™s yet to be seen whether De La Hoya caves to DAZNâ€™s demands to let the fight between Ortiz and Ennis proceed with a 50-50 purse split. De La Hoya previously claimed that the promotion is looking elsewhere for an opponent for Ortiz Jr. In the meantime, however, Vergil Ortiz Jr.â€™s manager is growing impatient with De La Hoyaâ€™s demand, which is causing the delay in making the fight against Jaron Ennis a reality.

Vergil Ortiz Jr.â€™s manager, Rick Mirigian, pushed back against GB Promotions chairman Oscar De La Hoya after he claimed the company was â€œmoving onâ€ from a potential fight with Jaron Ennis. Speaking to BoxingScene, Mirigian made it clear the decision was not Golden Boyâ€™s to make.

â€œI have the right to negotiate with anyone,â€ Mirigian said. â€œThey donâ€™t have the authorization to say [the deal must be] 60% to 40%â€”60-40 of what? You canâ€™t â€˜move onâ€™ when no one has spoken to us.â€ Mirigian stressed that Ortiz wants the fight and accused Golden Boy of presenting only one opponent and an inadequate financial offer.

â€œWe were given one number, and we gave a counter that was denied,â€ he explained. Rejecting claims that negotiations are over, Mirigian added, â€œWe are not â€˜moving on.â€™ We will negotiate. Vergil wants to make this fight, and so do I.â€

It appears Golden Boy Promotions has found itself in a difficult spot. Although they want the most money for their fighter, which will, of course, benefit them as well, Ortiz Jr. seems adamant about facing Ennis. Plus, DAZN is breathing down their neck to make the fight happen. Do you think it will?

The post Boots vs. Ortiz Drama Puts Oscar De La Hoyaâ€™s DAZN Future at Risk appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Tiger Shroff Joins Conor McGregor as Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship Expands to India (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship and Bare Knuckle Fight League are making their official entry into India, marking a significant expansion into one of the worldâ€™s largest combat sports markets. The move is being spearheaded by World League of Fighters, BKFCâ€™s license holder, which is co-founded by Rajesh Banga, Sunil Mathew and Siraj Gill. The organization â€¦
fullText:
Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship and Bare Knuckle Fight League are making their official entry into India, marking a significant expansion into one of the worldâ€™s largest combat sports markets.

The move is being spearheaded by World League of Fighters, BKFCâ€™s license holder, which is co-founded by Rajesh Banga, Sunil Mathew and Siraj Gill. The organization has brought in prominent film producer Parag Sanghvi and Bollywood star and martial artist Tiger Shroff to join the board alongside BKFC founder and president David Feldman and former two-division UFC champion Conor McGregor, who became a part-owner of BFKC in 2024.

Miss Universe Harnaaz Sandhu Joins Tiger Shroff, Sanjay Dutt in 'Baaghi 4' - Global Bulletin

Netflix, Amazon Prime, ZEE5, SonyLIV Vie for India's IFFI Streaming Honor - Global Bulletin

Fox Orders Lifeguard Drama Series 'Rescue: Hi-Surf' from Producer John Wells (TV News Roundup)

WLF previously delivered a sold-out BKFC event in Dubai last year, which the organization describes as the biggest bare-knuckle fighting event held in the Middle East.

The India expansion will introduce a team-based bare-knuckle league format â€“ marking the first time such a structure has been implemented in the history of the sport. The format will feature six inaugural teams: Crushers, Punishers, Warriors, Phantoms, Gladiators and Infernos, transforming individual fights into a franchise-based competition.

Rahul Saxena has been appointed CEO to lead the platform. He brings experience in scaling global brands to the role.

â€œIndia is not just a market â€“ it is the future of global combat sports,â€ Banga, Mathew and Gill said in a joint statement. â€œTogether with BKFC, BKFL and WLF, we are building an ecosystem that will develop Indian fighters, create global stars and deliver world-class fight entertainment to millions of fans.â€

Sanghvi positioned the venture as an opportunity to build a sports intellectual property from India with global reach. â€œThis is where world-class storytelling meets raw, uncompromising sport,â€ he said. â€œWith WLF, BKFC and Conor McGregor, we are not just launching a league â€“ we are architecting a global sports IP from India that will command attention, talent and fandom worldwide.â€

Feldman emphasized Indiaâ€™s longstanding position in the organizationâ€™s expansion strategy. â€œIndia has been on our roadmap for a long time,â€ he said. â€œThe scale, the energy, the culture â€” there is no place like it. With the leadership team we have assembled and our partnership with WLF, we are bringing the purest form of combat sports to a nation ready for it.â€

McGregor, who serves as a global partner for BKFC, framed the expansion as transformative. â€œIndia has warriors in its DNA,â€ he said. â€œWhat weâ€™re building with BKFC and BKFL in India will be something the world has never seen before. This is not just expansion â€“ this is a revolution.â€

Shroff, joining McGregor as a board member, highlighted the cultural significance of the venture. â€œHonored to stand alongside Conor McGregor as we create something truly historic for Indian sport,â€ he said. â€œThis is more than a fight â€“ itâ€™s a global movement, and history is being written. Just like cinema, sport is a celebration of talent and skill, and Parag [Sanghvi] and I are committed to turning this into a landmark moment for India.â€

The first official BKFC and BKFL team-based events are scheduled for 2026, with venue and fight card details to be announced.â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

title: Joshua Zirkzee left devastated by latest development
description: Following Ruben Amorimâ€™s sacking, quite a few plans have changed at Manchester United.A new caretaker in Michael Carrick has stepped in, new coaches have come in to assist him, and plenty of first-t...
fullText:
Following Ruben Amorimâ€™s sacking, quite a few plans have changed at Manchester United.

A new caretaker in Michael Carrick has stepped in, new coaches have come in to assist him, and plenty of first-team stars will hope their fortunes will also change as a result.

Quite a few players would have liked to have played more under the Portuguese, but their chances remained few and far between.

Kobbie Mainoo is one of them, so is Joshua Zirkzee. The Dutchman started a mere four games under the ex-Sporting CP boss.

With the World Cup coming up, he was desperate to play more in a bid to make the Netherlands team for the quadrennial showpiece.

Despite interest from England, all signs pointed towards a return to Italy where AS Roma were pushing the hardest.

In fact, at one stage, the Giallorossi had even agreed on the outlines of a deal and agreed personal terms with the forward.

However, INEOS blocked the deal, waiting for the caretaker to take the final call. And the final decision was that the 24-year-old would not be allowed to join the Serie A side.

And as per SportsBoom, that has left the former Bologna ace devastated as he wanted a fresh start and had even told his inner circle he expected to be playing in the Serie A from January onwards.

â€œManchester United striker Joshua Zirkzee has been left disgruntled after his move to Roma collapsed, SportsBoom can exclusively reveal.

â€œSources close to the player have said the Dutch international expected to be a Roma player by the end of the window.

â€œThe move has been mooted for months with Zirkzee struggling to make his mark at the Red Devils since his Â£36.5million move to Old Trafford last season. And Zirkzee is said to be disappointed his future has been left in limbo.â€

Joshua Zirkzee has two goals and one assist this season and did not start a single game under interim boss Darren Fletcher.

With Benjamin Sesko back amongst the goals, and with Bryan Mbeumo and Amad also back, it will be interesting to see how many minutes he gets under Michael Carrick.

Feature image Molly Darlington via Getty Images

The Peoples Person has been one of the worldâ€™s leading Man United news sites for over a decade. bsky.social

fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) â€” Morton did it to Washington again.

Paige Selke and Abby VanMeenen scored 12 points each as third-ranked Morton handed top-ranked Washington its first loss of the season, 41-37, in a match-up of teams at the top of the Mid-Illini Conference standings Tuesday at Morton High School. The hosts (15-3, 7-0) led by as many as 12 points in the third quarter then had to hang on as the Panthers (17-1, 7-1) rallied to close within two in the final seconds.

Last year, Morton went to No. 1 Washington and ended the Panthers season-opening 21-game win streak with a 46-45 win at Torry Gym. The Panthers returned the favor by beating the Potters in the regular season finale and in the sectional championship on the way to finishing third at state.

Penelope Drake scored nine points for the Potters but may have delivered the gameâ€™s biggest play when she blocked a three-point shot by Washingtonâ€™s Avery Tibbs with 0:15 left as Washington was aiming to tie the game. Tibbs finished with a game-high 14 points.

The two teams will meet again on Feb. 10 in the final game of the regular season in Washington.

Other girls basketball winners included Notre Dame, Richwoods, Normal Community, Normal West, Metamora, Canton. Pekin, and Illini Bluffs. Boys basketball winners Tuesday included Normal Community, Normal West, Richwoods, Manual, Washington, Leroy, Fieldcrest, El Paso-Gridley, Elmwood and Peoria Heights.

title: What happened in high school hoops Tuesday? Here are your scores and recaps
description: Girls basketball was the star of the show on Tuesday night and we've got the stories and scores from those games, the boys and some other sports all in the Journal Hoops Wrap.
fullText:
Editor's note: Coaches are reminded to send in game results each weeknight, from 6-10 p.m., by emailing them toÂ pjsports@providencejournal.com

Marielle NassiffÂ provided some offensive pop in the third quarter that gave the Quakers the separation they needed to close out the Purple in their 51-37 win.

The first quarter was tough defensive basketball, as Moses Brown led 9-4, then took a 24-15 lead into halftime thanks to nine points from Nassiff and six fromÂ Lauren BousquetÂ in the second quarter.

With Classical still hanging around, the Quakers revved up the defensive measures. They limited the Purple to just five points in the third quarter and Nassiff got herself some buckets, scoring eight points in the stretch to build a 42-20 lead heading to the fourth quarter.

Nassiff finished as Moses Brownâ€™s top scorer with 23 points. Bousquet was right behind her with 21 points andÂ Adelaide CrosbyÂ andÂ Madison WilsonÂ accounted for the remaining seven points.

Jaydell HarrisÂ was the top scorer for Classical, putting up 12 points.Â Daniella JimenezÂ had seven in the loss.

Cranston Westâ€™s offense was feeling good on Tuesday night.

The Falcons made seven 3-pointers â€¦ in the first quarter against the Rebels. The early shooting led to a 28-point frame as Cranston West toppled South Kingston, 74-36, on the road in a Division I matchup.

Cranston West finished with 13 treys in the game withÂ Talya WalkerÂ (19 points) making five from distance.Â Kyla BucoÂ (18 points) was right behind her with four makes from beyond the arc. Walker and Buco each made three triples in the opening frame.

Saniyya ChaseÂ scored a dozen points andÂ Madeleine MarquesÂ added 11 in the victory. It was the Falconsâ€™ best offensive game of the season by a wide margin as the Falcons hadnâ€™t broken 60 points yet this season. Might Tuesdayâ€™s win spark a run for Cranston West?

An important matchup with Westerly awaits on Saturday at home.

It was close all night, but Chariho pulled out a nailbiter vs. St. Raphael in Division I play.

The Chargers carried just a 6-point lead into the break and that was enough to hold off the Saints behindÂ Tessa Aielloâ€™sÂ 16 points. With scoring contributions from six different players, the Chargers used their balanced attack to secure their fourth win of the year.

Menuhki HarrisÂ managed a dozen points and had 10 fouls shots in the game as the junior was tough to defend. The Chargers added six points from the line in their decisive 14-point fourth quarter that helped keep them ahead.

Adrianna NokaÂ supplied eight points in the win. Tuesday was a key win at home for the Chargers as they travel to Westerly on Thursday night for a rivalry match. Chariho could play upset against the Bulldogs, who are looking like one of the best teams in the state to start the year.

SRA was paced by 16 points from Carolyn Abreu. The Saints host West Warwick on Thursday.

Genesis Castro scored a team-high 18 points, including 4 buckets from beyond the arc, and teammates Ella Martin and Faith Van Ness added 13 and 11 points, respectively, in the Eagles victory, as Barrington is now 10-1 and ranked second to only Westerly in Division I.

For the Patriots in the loss, Annie Hurd scored 16 points with 2 threes, Violet Silvia acced 11 points and 3 treys, and Gyselle Mairs finished with 10 points and 2 threes. Portsmouth slips to 5-2 on the season.

The Skippers wasted little time in dispatching the Rams in his Division I clash, racing out to a 24-3 advantage and playing a solid defensive game to cruise to victory. BrookeÂ FaunceÂ led the way with a game-high 16 points andÂ MyaÂ MacchioniÂ added 8 more as North Kingstown pushed its record to 6-3 with its second win over La Salle (2-8) this season.

For the Rams,Â MayaÂ FernandesÂ led the team with 6 points as La Salle gears up to face Portsmouth later this week.

Westerly continues to prove itâ€™s one of the stateâ€™s best programs.

The Bulldogs handled Pawtucket comfortably in a 65-23 victory on Tuesday night at home. Westerly assisted on 24 of its 27 field goals withÂ Macy Antochâ€™s 14 points pacing the group. The freshman also supplied four rebounds and four steals in a standout night in the Division I matchup.

Danica JarrettÂ was right behind her teammate with 13 points, five rebounds and a trio of steals.Â Cece SaintÂ rounded out Westerlyâ€™s scorers in double figures with 10 points. But the standout performers donâ€™t end there. Santanaa Hamelin supplied seven assists and seven steals as the freshman was all over the court.

The young, and talented, Bulldogs are now 9-1 overall on the year and host Chariho on Thursday.

East Providence girls basketball rebounded in a big way Tuesday night.

The Division II Townies managed a season-high 57 points in their 57-43 victory against Division Iâ€™s West Warwick. The win comes on the heels of EP losing to Rogers last Friday.

Zarae HallÂ got East Providence started hot with 14 points in the first half and finished off the Wizards with 24 in the game. The junior made 10 shots from the field, including a trio of 3-pointers to push EP to its fifth win of the season.

Trinity ProvencherÂ added a dozen points, including eight in the fourth quarter to close out the hosts.Â Audrey BernardÂ supplied another dozen points as EPâ€™s offense was firing on all cylinders. East Providence travels to Tiverton on Friday.

West Warwick was led by Brea Limaâ€™s 18 points and Alexa Foleyâ€™s 14.The Wizards meet St. Raphael on Thursday in Pawtucket.

The Vikings believe in the old adage that you only get one chance to make a first impression. So opening the game with a 17-point first quarter, and then adding 18 in the second was pretty indicative of how this Division II contest would play out.

Rogers started hot and stayed that way. They were paced by the dynamic duo ofÂ ZaidaÂ AponteÂ â€“Â 21 points, including four 3's â€“Â andÂ TamekaÂ RobertsonÂ â€“Â 14 first half points. The result was a 35-17 lead by the break and an easier second half.

For the Mariners,Â TaylorÂ SullivanÂ andÂ DelaneyÂ BonneauÂ each scored 11 points, with Sullivan making a pair of 3-pointers and Bonneau going 6-fo-6 at the foul line.

Rogers moves to 4-2 and will have a stiff test coming later this week when it faces first-place Coventry (8-1).

Freshman Eveisha Santana had a night to remember as she poured in 26 points, 6 from beyond the arc, pulled down 8 rebounds and had 5 steals and 4 assists to lead the Knights to a win over the Villa Novans. Also factoring in the win was Keeana Palmer who had 8 points, 5 boards, 3 steals and 4 assists. Central improved to 7-1 on the season.

Skyla Caro topped Woonsocket in scoring with 11 points and teammate Akira Moise added 8 points in the loss.

Lincoln School 53, Mt. Hope, 29

The Cavaliers made it two in a row on back to back nights, matching last season's win total (three) in the young season. Juanita Sanchez was up 39-21 at the break and was never threatened in the second half

The Cavs were led by Geston Richardson with 25 points and Corey McClain, who added 17. Amaree Gomes and Allen Ortiz also scored in double figures in the win. The Patriots were led by James Nute (11 points) and Josh Morales (10).

Smithfield 47, North Kingstown 40

title: High school boys basketball: American Fork cleanly defends home against region rival Lone Peak
description: High school boys basketball: American Fork cleanly defends home against region rival Lone Peak
fullText:
It didnâ€™t take long for American Fork to get rolling in its Region 3 rivalry matchup with Lone Peak on Tuesday. The offense was hot, and the Knights struggled to stop it as American Fork rolled to a 77-63 home win.

The Cavemen went to the basics early and drove into the paint. American Fork didnâ€™t need many outside shots to build its early 19-11 lead.

The lead only grew from there after Lone Peak attempted a full-court press and double-team heavy defense. Possession after possession, American Fork broke down the defense with smart passes, mostly through the high post.

Center Jax Clark made his presence known early by pulling in rebounds and getting easy buckets at the rim.

The Cavemen were playing fast and free, and nearly everyone on the court was getting action. American Fork sophomore Dieter Tuitavuki especially played well off the bench with 14 bench points, which includes three 3-pointers.

Sam Rutter, a smaller guard on the court, got an offensive rebound, putback, and then took a charge on the following defensive possession.

The fast and free offense even gave American Fork ample opportunities from beyond the arc, and the offense hit four in the second quarter alone.

It was plays like that which gave American Fork a dominant 39-18 lead at halftime.

â€œWe came out really hungry early, and we were aggressive, and we shot shots,â€ said American Fork head coach Ryan Cuff. â€œOne thing about what you do when you press is that you get teams to continue to shoot shots and try to shoot out of it. I thought there were some shots that were rusty, but a lot of our shots were still layups. We controlled the tempo a little bit that way.â€

Lone Peak continued its press-heavy defense into the second half with more success, but more importantly, it was finally hitting shots. Knightsâ€™ guard Saxon Young struggled with his shot at points of the game, but hit two threes in the third quarter.

The Knightsâ€™ offense scored 24 in the third quarter, but American Fork kept chugging along with 20 of its own. Utah State commit Bryce Mella played especially well by getting to the rim, scoring efficiently, and ended the night with 21 points.

The field goals were much harder to come by in the fourth quarter thanks to the Lone Peak defense, and for the first time since the first half, Lone Peak cut it to single digits.

That problem was made worse with errors at the free-throw line. However, American Fork made sure to seal the win by continuing to fight through the press and getting to the free-throw line.

â€œThey fought hard and give (Lone Peak) credit,â€ Cuff said. â€œWe get up, and the thing thatâ€™s scary about getting up, you donâ€™t want to celebrate. Not that we did, but sometimes you get that lead, and now youâ€™re trying to protect it. I was proud of us. We kept attacking. We got layups when they were there.â€

The win already gives American Fork sole control of the top spot in Region 3, but thereâ€™s still a lot of season to go. It beat Lehi in its region opener last week and will play Corner Canyon on Friday.

title: Bam Adebayo Hit With â€œRecruitmentâ€ Allegations After Hitting Ja Morantâ€™s Celebration Amid Trade Rumors
description: Ja Morant might be on the trade block and if so, will arguably be the hottest commodity on the market, with a host of teams reportedly willing to bring him on board. Of course, there is no certainty about where he will land, but Bam Adebayo may have just spoiled it for those who enjoy sudden bombshells dropped on social media.
fullText:
Ja Morant might be on the trade block and if so, will arguably be the hottest commodity on the market, with a host of teams reportedly willing to bring him on board. Of course, there is no certainty about where he will land, but Bam Adebayo may have just spoiled it for those who enjoy sudden bombshells dropped on social media.

Adebayo hit a clutch three-pointer from the left wing that ultimately helped the Miami Heat beat the Phoenix Suns 127-121 on Tuesday night, and he celebrated by seemingly calling Morantover to South Beach. He copied Morantâ€™s â€œgrenadeâ€ celebration.

When Morant first introduced the controversial celebration, he mimicked pulling the pin from a grenade and tossing it toward the crowd, then followed it up by covering his ears. The pin gesture eventually stopped, but the ear-covering did not. And Adebayo did just that.

It did not take long for the NBA community to realize that it was a nod to Ja, or at least that is what the majority believed. Morantâ€™s celebrations are unique and not something others resort to on a daily basis. So, Adebayo doing it at a time when it is common knowledge that Morant could be on his way out of Memphis makes the idea that he is trying to lure Morant to Miami seem extremely plausible.

There have also been strong rumors linking Morant to the Heat, with NBA journalist Rachel Nichols even revealing that the franchise is interested in him. It would be an intriguing addition and would certainly inject some life into a Heat team that needs inspiration heading into the postseason.

On the other hand, Zach Lowe has explicitly stated that the Heat donâ€™t want to sign the controversial superstar.

Morant himself has not commented on the Heat at all. It remains to be seen whether these are merely murmurs or something more concrete, because a grenade celebration alone cannot determine a trade.

After all, Jaren Jackson Jr. of the Grizzlies did the same celebration in Memphisâ€™ last game. That does not mean Morant will now want to remain in Tennessee.

The post Bam Adebayo Hit With â€œRecruitmentâ€ Allegations After Hitting Ja Morantâ€™s Celebration Amid Trade Rumors appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Antetokounmpo responds with boos of his own after home crowd jeers Bucks during lopsided loss
description: Giannis Antetokounmpo couldnâ€™t remember hearing boos from his home crowd during his brilliant 13-year career in Milwaukee.  It happened Tuesday midway through the Bucksâ€™ 139-106 loss to a Minnesota Timberwolves team that was playing without Anthony Edwards and Rudy Gobert.  â€œIâ€™ve never been a part of something like that before,â€ Antetokounmpo said after the game.
fullText:
MILWAUKEE (AP) â€” Giannis Antetokounmpo couldnâ€™t remember hearing boos from his home crowd during his brilliant 13-year career in Milwaukee.

It happened Tuesday midway through the Bucksâ€™ 139-106 loss to a Minnesota Timberwolves team that was playing without Anthony Edwards and Rudy Gobert.

â€œIâ€™ve never been a part of something like that before,â€ Antetokounmpo said after the game. â€œSomething new for me.â€

The two-time MVP responded the same way he has whenever heâ€™s been booed on the road. After making a driving layup and drawing a foul in the opening minute of the third quarter, Antetokounmpo offered a thumbs-down gesture and booed back.

â€œWhen I get booed, I boo back,â€ Antetokounmpo said. â€œIâ€™ve been doing it all season.â€

Those boos poured down after Milwaukee trailed 76-45 at the break. Never before in franchise history had the Timberwolves built such a big halftime lead in a road game.

Antetokounmpo acknowledged the Bucksâ€™ effort was low Tuesday. He also expanded on why the boos bothered him.

â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s fair,â€ Antetokounmpo said. â€œBut everybody has their opinion to do what they want to do. Iâ€™m not going to tell them what to do and how they should act when we donâ€™t play hard or win, or we lose games or weâ€™re not where weâ€™re supposed to be. And I donâ€™t think anybody has the right to tell me how I should act on the basketball court after Iâ€™ve been here 13 years and Iâ€™m basically the all-time leader in everything.â€

The Bucksâ€™ latest loss came as they approach the midway point of a season that hasnâ€™t met their expectations.

Milwaukee (17-23) is 11th in the Eastern Conference standings, meaning the Bucks would have to rally in the second half just to reach the play-in round of the postseason. Thatâ€™s a precipitous fall for a team that has made nine straight playoff appearances and won the NBA title in 2021.

The Bucksâ€™ precarious position means they canâ€™t afford to have performances like the one they delivered against a short-handed Minnesota team Tuesday. Milwaukee coach Doc Rivers blamed it on â€œdead legsâ€ after the game, noting the Bucks had just returned from a four-game trip and are about to go back on the road for their next two contests.

â€œDead legs cannot be an excuse,â€ Antetokounmpo said. â€œWe have to be better.â€

Antetokounmpo noted that the improvement must start with him, though he delivered 25 points, eight rebounds and five assists on Tuesday. He was asked how the Bucks could step up in the second half to put themselves back in playoff position.

â€œPlaying hard,â€ Antetokounmpo said. â€œPlaying the right way. Playing selfless basketball, which we donâ€™t. I donâ€™t know. I really donâ€™t know. Those three things are important. I know that theyâ€™re important for you to win. Right now thereâ€™s so many things that we can do better. Letâ€™s just start by, â€™Can we just play harder? Can we just play the right way? Can we create advantages for the next player? Can we just play for our teammate, play for the team, play for ourselves?' Letâ€™s start with that, and I think everything will follow.â€

Antetokounmpo has offered similar messages after other losses this season, but the Bucks still havenâ€™t put it all together. They havenâ€™t won more than two straight games at any point this season.

â€œMaybe we are not connected as much as we should,â€ Antetokounmpo said. â€œMaybe my voice is just a broken record and guys are just tired and guys might tend to do what they want to do. I donâ€™t know. But as a leader, it doesnâ€™t matter. Being a leader is the same thing as being a dad. You have to keep on being available, being consistent with your words and your actions over and over and over again. One day you hope the message is going to go through.â€

In the meantime, Antetokounmpo says he will keep responding to boos the same way, no matter whoâ€™s doing the jeering.

â€œI thrive through adversity,â€ Antetokounmpo said. â€œI thrive when people donâ€™t believe in me. Doesnâ€™t matter if Iâ€™m on the road, if Iâ€™m at home, if Iâ€™m at my family dinner, if Iâ€™m at a practice facility against my teammate.â€

AP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA

title: Zach Hyman's Bizarre Scoring Streak: Three Goals, Eight Inches From The Net
description: Zach Hyman has been doing nothing but score lately. The catch? It's been in the strangest ways possible.
fullText: Zach Hyman has been doing nothing but score lately. The catch? It's been in the strangest ways possible. Against Chicago, he kicked the puck off his thigh and into the net. It was waived off, but still. Against Nashville tonight, he added two power play goals, both from right on top of the crease. His last three goals have come from a combined total of eight inches away from the net. He's not sniping from the circles or roofing backhands from the slot. He's camping in the blue paint, getting whacked, cross-checked, and somehow finding ways to jam pucks past goalies. Fourteen goals in his last 17 games. That's a lot of production from a guy who wasn't scoring much at all early in the season after returning from injury. But the Edmonton Oilers weren't worried. Not even a little bit. The organization has analysts doing every job imaginable, tracking every stat any fan could ever want to know. One of those stats is expected goalsâ€”basically, a measure of the quality of scoring chances a player is generating based on shot location, type, and situation. And when Hyman wasn't scoring early on, his expected goals said he should have been. He was getting chances. High-quality chances. The puck just wasn't going in. Kris Knoblauch had a simple take on it: Hyman was overdue, and when it started happening, watch out. From Rink Rats To NHLers: The Dad Trip Brings It Full Circle The Edmonton Oilers' dad trip started in Chicago yesterday and wraps up tonight in Nashville. It's one of those NHL traditions that doesn't get enough attention from the outside, but for the players and their fathers, it's special in a way that's hard to put into words. Turns out Knoblauch makes the big bucks for a reason. He was right. Once Hyman broke through, the floodgates opened. Now he can't stop scoring, even if those goals come from the most unglamorous spots on the ice. That's Hyman's game. He doesn't score highlight-reel goals from the hashmarks. He scores garbage goals. Net-front scrambles. Deflections. Rebounds. Pucks that trickle through the goalie's pads while he's being cross-checked in the spine. It's not glamorous, but it works. Fourteen goals in 17 games proves that. Unfortunately, last night it wasn't enough. The Oilers played sloppy against Nashville. Turnovers they'd love to have back. Defensive breakdowns that cost them. Hyman did his partâ€”two power play goals, both from right on top of the netâ€”but the team couldn't overcome their own mistakes. Oilers at Nashville: Pre-game Stats 23-16-7 | 53 PTS Still, Hyman's recent stretch is a reminder of what he brings to this team beyond just goals. He fights. He finishes checks. He screens goalies until they can't see anything. He gets to the net. He parks himself there and refuses to move. Honestly, if Connor McDavid asked him to throw on the goalie gear, he'd probably do it without hesitation. That's the value of Zach Hyman. He does whatever it takes. When he wasn't scoring early in the season, he was still doing all the other stuffâ€”forechecking, creating space for McDavid, battling in corners, killing penalties. The goals weren't coming, but the effort never wavered. And the Oilers knew, based on the underlying numbers, that eventually the puck luck would turn. Better Than Advertised: Ingram's Play Forces Tough Questions in Edmonton Connor Ingram's performance Monday night against the Blackhawks was something else. When the Edmonton Oilers traded for him, I'll be the first to admit it: I didn't think he was the answer. I still don't think he's some saviour who's going to single-handedly carry this team to a Cup. But he's proven to be better than what we all gave him credit for. He can come in and win games for Edmonton. He's reliable. He's steady. He's the kind of goaltender that doesn't make Connor McDavid and Leon Draisaitl worry about what's happening behind them. Expected goals are a useful tool because they cut through short-term variance. Sometimes players go through stretches where they can't buy a goal despite doing everything right. Other times, players go on heaters that aren't sustainable based on the quality of their chances. Hyman's early-season drought was the former. His current run is the payoff. He was generating quality chances all along; now they're actually going in. And they're going in from ridiculous distances. Three goals from a combined eight inches away. That's absurd. He's made a living this season out of being in the exact spot goalies hate most: right on top of them, stick on the ice, ready to bang home anything that comes near the crease. The Oilers need that. McDavid and Draisaitl can create offence from anywhere on the ice, but having a guy who's willing to pay the price in front of the net is invaluable. Hyman absorbs punishment, battles through cross-checks, and still finds ways to get his stick on pucks. It's a skillset that doesn't always show up in highlight packages, but it wins games. Like Father, Like Son: Leon Draisaitl's Hockey DNA Runs Deep Leon Draisaitl is one of the best players in the NHL. He's a perennial Hart Trophy candidate, a scoring machine, and Connor McDavid's partner in crime on one of the most dangerous duos in hockey. But before all that, he was just a kid hanging around the rink, watching his dad play. The other night in Nashville, it almost did. Two power play goals from Hyman, both from his office right on the goal line. But sloppy play elsewhere cost the Oilers. Sometimes that happens. The good news? Hyman's rolling. Fourteen goals in 17 games, with no signs of slowing down. Knoblauch called it. Hyman was overdue. Now he's cashing in. And as long as he keeps parking himself inches from the net, the goals will keep comingâ€”no matter how weird they look. BookmarkÂ The Hockey News Edmonton OilersÂ team site to never miss theÂ latest news,Â game-dayÂ coverage, andÂ more.Â Â Â Add us to yourÂ Google NewsÂ favourites, and never miss a story.

title: Longhorns Daily News: Georgia Tech DC Blake Gideon returns to Texas
description: Blake Gideon, who coaches Texas footballâ€™s safeties from 2021 to 2024, has so far spent just one season as the defensive coordinator at Georgia Tech.
